Name: Anchovy (Atlantic)
Description: Small fish, known for their strong flavour when cured.
Explanation: The MCS rates Atlantic anchovy as 2-3, and is currently evaluating other fisheries. The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that anchovy from the Black and Mediterranean seas is unsustainable.

Name: Anchovy (Other)
Description: Small fish, known for their strong flavour when cured.
Explanation: The MCS rates Atlantic anchovy as 2-3, and is currently evaluating other fisheries. The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that anchovy from the Black and Mediterranean seas is unsustainable.

Name: Arctic Char
Description: A freshwater fish related to salmon and trout. Char are farmed in land-based systems that minimize environmental impact and require relatively little feed.
Explanation: The MCS approves of eating both farmed and wild-caught arctic char. The Monterey Bay Aquarium and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Barramundi (US/Europe/Australia)
Description: A popular fish in Thai cuisine and in Australia. It is fished and farmed across the world. Also called Asian seabass.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that US and Australian barramundi is generally good to eat, as is other barramundi that is farmed in closed systems. The MCS, FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Barramundi (Closed Production)
Description: A popular fish in Thai cuisine and in Australia. It is fished and farmed across the world. Also called Asian seabass.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that US and Australian barramundi is generally good to eat, as is other barramundi that is farmed in closed systems. The MCS, FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Barramundi (Other)
Description: A popular fish in Thai cuisine and in Australia. It is fished and farmed across the world. Also called Asian seabass.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that US and Australian barramundi is generally good to eat, as is other barramundi that is farmed in closed systems. The MCS, FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Bream (Organic Farmed Gilthead Bream)
Description: Also called daurade or dorada, a popular Mediterranean fish that is unfortunately farmed in an environmentally damaging way - but organic certified Gilthead Bream is fine according to the MCS.
Explanation: The MCS rates organic farmed gilthead bream as a 2, but other kinds of bream as a 4-5. The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists gilthead farmed in closed tanks as a Best Choice.

Name: Bream (Other)
Description: Other types of bream such as red seabream are unsustainable.
Explanation: The MCS rates organic farmed gilthead bream as a 2, but other kinds of bream as a 4-5. The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists gilthead farmed in closed tanks as a Best Choice.

Name: Brown Crab
Description: A reddish-brown crab with an oval carapace sporting a characteristic wavy "pie crust" edge. Stocks may be on the brink of decline.
Explanation: The Marine Conservation Society rates pot-caught crab as 2, is evaluating some other fisheries, and raises concerns that the stock levels are showing indications of declining, and are not formally assessed. The Monterey Bay Aquarium and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Catfish
Description: A very popular farmed fish in the US, their vegetarian diet makes them low-impact.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists US farmed catfish as a Best Choice and other catfish as a good alternative. The MCS rates catfish as a 2-3.

Name: Clam (Ocean Quahog)
Description: Clams are generally sustainable, and stock levels are good. Greenpeace quotes destructive fishing methods, habitat impact, and poor fishery management as reasons for putting the Ocean Quahog on the red list.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates all clams as Best Choice or Good Alternative, but Greenpeace quotes destructive fishing methods, habitat impact, and poor fishery management as reasons for putting the Ocean Quahog on the red list. The MCS is assessing its information and has no data.

Name: Clam (Other)
Description: Clams are generally sustainable, and stock levels are good.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates all clams as Best Choice or Good Alternative, but Greenpeace quotes destructive fishing methods, habitat impact, and poor fishery management as reasons for putting the Ocean Quahog on the red list. The MCS is assessing its information and has no data.

Name: Cockle (Dredged)
Description: Small saltwater clams with a round, ribbed shell. Avoid cockles harvested by dredging as this damages the seafloor.
Explanation: The MCS advises against consuming dredged cockles as dredging damages the sea floor. Hand-gathered cockles are rated 2. The Monterey Bay Aquarium, FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Cockle (Hand Gathered)
Description: Small saltwater clams with a round, ribbed shell. Hand-gathered cockles are generally screened for size and are very sustainable.
Explanation: The MCS advises against consuming dredged cockles as dredging damages the sea floor. Hand-gathered cockles are rated 2. The Monterey Bay Aquarium, FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Cod
Description: A very popular mild-flavoured white fish that is sadly very much overfished. Try pollack, coley or gurnard instead.
Explanation: Data on cod is very contradictory, and there is no clear and easy rule to determine what cod is sustainable.

Name: Coley/Saithe (Iceland)
Description: A good alternative to cod, recognisable by a distinctive white line running along its side.
Explanation: The Marine Conservation Society rates coley as 2-4 depending on capture area.

Name: Coley/Saithe (Other)
Description: A good alternative to cod, recognisable by a distinctive white line running along its side.
Explanation: The Marine Conservation Society rates coley as 2-4 depending on capture area.

Name: Crayfish (US)
Description: River-dwelling crustaceans resembling small lobsters, commonly farmed in ponds.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that US farmed crayfish are a "Best Choice", but to "Avoid" imported ones. The MCS, FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data. So while this view is probably too US-centric, in the absence of further information, US crayfish is rated as sustainable and all other crayfish is not.

Name: Crayfish (Other)
Description: River-dwelling crustaceans resembling small lobsters, commonly farmed in ponds. Crayfish from China in particular are not recommended.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that US farmed crayfish are a "Best Choice", but to "Avoid" imported ones. The MCS, FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data. So while this view is probably too US-centric, in the absence of further information, US crayfish is rated as sustainable and all other crayfish is not.

Name: Dab
Description: A kind of flatfish similar to the plaice and flounder.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists dab as "Avoid", while the MCS rates it at a 2-3.

Name: Dogfish
Description: Dogfish are small sharks, and as such are not sustainable, as they are few in number and reproduce only slowly.
Explanation: The MCS rates dogfish as 3-5. As a kind of shark, dogfish are on the Greenpeace red list.

Name: Eel
Description: Long, bottom-feeding fish. Both farmed and wild caught eels are very problematic: Farming produces a lot of pollution and eel fisheries are over-exploiting stocks and causing habitat damage. Popular in sushi, but please avoid.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists eel as "Avoid", and the MCS lists all types of eel as 5 - very unsustainable.

Name: European Perch
Description: A popular food and angling fish found in Europe and Asia. Considered an invasive species in Australia.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium, Greenpeace, the MCS, and FishWatch have no data. The IUCN rates it as "Least Concern".

Name: Flounder
Description: A kind of flatfish similar to the plaice and dab.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists flounders as a mixture of Good Alternative and Avoid, while the MCS rates them as a 3. On balance, flounder not known to be specifically sustainable should be avoided.

Name: Grenadier/Hoki/Whiptail
Description: A long-lived, slow-breeding, deep-sea fish with thin tails. Also called hoki, blue hake or whiptail. Grenadiers only begin breeding at 20 to 40 years. As a result, stocks are very fragile.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates MSC certified grenadier as a good alternative, but the MCS rate it as 5, and it's on the Greenpeace red list.

Name: Gurnard
Description: A good alternative to cod, gurnard is currently often treated as by-catch and discarded.
Explanation: The MCS lists three different kinds of gurnard, rating them 3. The Monterey Bay Aquarium and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Haddock
Description: A popular fish easily recognised by a distinctive black line running along its side.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists some haddock as "Good Alternative", other as "Avoid". The MCS shows a very mixed picture, with some Atlantic populations rated 2, and others rated 5. In conclusion, some haddock may be sustainable, but hard to identify as such.

Name: Herring (North Sea)
Description: A popular oily fish often seen pickled or fried. Fisheries in the North Sea are carefully managed and hence sustainable.
Explanation: The sustainability of herring heavily depends on its source, with the MCS listing 19 different kinds of sources rated between 1-5. North Sea herring appears to be the most reliably sustainable option. Be very careful to ensure correct sourcing.

Name: Herring (Other)
Description: A popular oily fish often seen pickled or fried. Many herring fisheries, especially in the Baltic and around parts of Scotland and Ireland are in an extremely bad condition, with stocks near-eradicated.
Explanation: The sustainability of herring heavily depends on its source, with the MCS listing 19 different kinds of sources rated between 1-5. North Sea herring appears to be the most reliably sustainable option. Be very careful to ensure correct sourcing.

Name: John Dory
Description: Recognizable by a dark spot on its side and a spiny crest, the john dory or peter's fish is vulnerable and often taken as bycatch from trawls.
Explanation: The MCS rates john dory as 3.

Name: King Crab (US)
Description: Large, red, spiky crabs. Critically overfished in Russia, where most imported crabs come from. US-sourced king crab may be OK.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates US king crab as a "Good Alternative", but other king crab as "Avoid".

Name: King Crab (Other)
Description: Large, red, spiky crabs. Critically overfished in Russia, where most imported crabs come from. US-sourced king crab may be OK.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates US king crab as a "Good Alternative", but other king crab as "Avoid".

Name: King Prawn (Organic Farmed)
Description: Large pink prawns. Organically certified farms reduce the environmental damage that may be caused by prawn farming.
Explanation: The MCS rates organically farmed king prawns as 1, and prawns from other sources as 3-5. The Monterey Bay Aquarium and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: King Prawn (Other Farmed)
Description: Large pink prawns. Prawn farming may cause: destruction of habitats through conversion into pond systems, nutrient runoff, freshwater lakes being turned into saltwater and the spread of disease to wild prawns. Prawns require a lot of fishmeal that tends to come from unclear sources.
Explanation: The MCS rates organically farmed king prawns as 1, and prawns from other sources as 3-5. The Monterey Bay Aquarium and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: King Prawn (Wild Caught)
Description: Large pink prawns. Fished tiger prawns are not environmentally sustainable.
Explanation: The MCS rates organically farmed king prawns as 1, and prawns from other sources as 3-5. The Monterey Bay Aquarium and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Lobster (Mexican and European)
Description: Large, large-clawed crustacean. Lobsters can live for at least a hundred years, and there are indications that they may not die of old age at all. Many lobster stocks are inaedequately managed and monitored.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates Mexican lobster as "Best Choice" while painting a complex picture of US lobster. The MCS rates European lobster as 1-2.

Name: Lobster (Other)
Description: Large, large-clawed crustacean. Lobsters can live for at least a hundred years, and there are indications that they may not die of old age at all. Many lobster stocks are inaedequately managed and monitored.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates Mexican lobster as "Best Choice" while painting a complex picture of US lobster. The MCS rates European lobster as 1-2.

Name: Mackerel
Description: A dark-fleshed fish often found smoked or canned. Stocks are generally OK but avoid Mediterranean mackerel.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists mackerel as "Best Choice" or "Good Alternative". The MCS is currently evaluating its data.

Name: Mahi-Mahi/Dolphinfish
Description: A large, bright yellow fish with a large back fin.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists mahi mahi from the US as "Best Choice" and other non-longline fished mahi mahi as a "Good Alternative", except for fish from Costa Rica, Guatemala and Peru. The MCS rates it as 2-3. As a large and badly monitored fish, it is potentially threatened, but in the absence of evidence for this, it is labeled as "sustainable".

Name: Marlin
Description: A large and very fast predatory fish with a large back fin. Stocks are in very poor condition and very badly managed.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates most marlin as "Avoid", with the exception of Hawaiian marlin, which is rates as a "Good Alternative". The MCS rates all marlin as 4-5.

Name: Monkfish
Description: A bottom-dwelling anglerfish with a wide toothy mouth. Also known as ankoh, angler  or goosefish. Monkfish are caught by bottom trawls that badly damage the seafloor and produce a lot of bycatch, or by gillnets that kill turtles and dolphins.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates Atlantic monkfish as a good alternative, but the MCS rates it as 4. It is also on the Greenpeace red list.

Name: Mussels
Description: Farmed mussels do not require feeding or chemical treatment and hence have a very low environmental impact. Wild mussels are generally sustainable, but avoid ones harvested by dredging as this damages the seafloor.
Explanation: The MCS and Monterey Bay Aquarium agree that farmed mussels are very sustainable. According to the MCS, farmed mussels are rated 1 while others are under evaluation.

Name: Northern Prawn
Description: Small pink prawns.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates northern shrimp from Alaska as a "Best Choice". The MCS rates northern prawn from the atlantic as 1-2.

Name: Orange Roughy/Slimehead
Description: A large sedentary fish living in deep waters. It is slow-growing and late to mature, and not sustainable as a food source.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates orange roughy as "Avoid", and it's on the Greenpeace red list. The MCS and FishWatch and have no data.

Name: Oysters
Description: Oyster farms have very little environmental impact. Avoid dredged wild oysters, as their harvesting can seriously damage the seafloor.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium approves oysters, and the MCS is currently evaluating its data and has no advice. Wild oysters may be problematic due to environmental damage caused by dredging, but most oysters are farmed. FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Pangasius (Certifié GlobalGAP/ASC)
Description: A mild-flavoured kind of catfish commonly farmed in Asia. Prefer ASC or GlobalGap-certified fish, as other farmed Pangasius can badly impact the environment.
Explanation: The MCS rates ASC certified pangasius as 2 and GlobalGAP certified fish as 3. No information is given on other pangasius, implying it is not sustainable.

Name: Pangasius (Other)
Description: A mild-flavoured kind of catfish commonly farmed in Asia. Prefer ASC or GlobalGap-certified fish, as other farmed Pangasius can badly impact the environment.
Explanation: The MCS rates ASC certified pangasius as 2 and GlobalGAP certified fish as 3. No information is given on other pangasius, implying it is not sustainable.

Name: Pink Shrimp (Alaska and Canada)
Description: Small pink crustaceans.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists pink shrimp from Alaska as a "Best Choice" and Canadian shrimp as a "Good Alternative", but advises against pink shrimp from other sources, especially Louisiana and Mexico.

Name: Pink Shrimp (MSC Certified)
Description: Small pink crustaceans.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists pink shrimp from Alaska as a "Best Choice" and Canadian shrimp as a "Good Alternative", but advises against pink shrimp from other sources, especially Louisiana and Mexico.

Name: Pink Shrimp (Other)
Description: Small pink crustaceans.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists pink shrimp from Alaska as a "Best Choice" and Canadian shrimp as a "Good Alternative", but advises against pink shrimp from other sources, especially Louisiana and Mexico.

Name: Plaice
Description: A very popular and very overfished flatfish.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists plaice as a "Good Alternative". The MCS rates plaice as 3-5.

Name: Pollock/Pollack
Description: A relative of the cod, it is a good alternative to that fish.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists all pollock apart from Icelandic pollock as "Best Choice"/"Good Alternative". The MCS rates it as 2-3.

Name: Pouting/Bib
Description: Living on the European coast, pouting is mostly caught as bycatch. Eat it instead of having it thrown back or ground into fishmeal.
Explanation: The MCS rates pouting as 2. The Monterey Bay Aquarium and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Ray
Description: Cartilaginous fish with "wings" and a long, thin tail. They are severely overfished and in decline.
Explanation: The MCS rates all rays as 5. Greenpeace has rays on its red list. The Monterey Bay Aquarium has no data.

Name: Razor Clam
Description: Razor clam stocks are depleted and badly managed. They are threatened by an illegal fishing method known as "electric fishing", where electrodes dragged along the sea bed are used to chase them out of their burrows.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lumps in razor clams along with other clams as "Best Choice". However, the MCS paints a different picture, rating them 3-5 depending on the method of collection.

Name: Salmon (Organic Farmed)
Description: The MCS rates most farmed salmon as a bad choice but makes an exception for organic-certified European salmon.
Explanation: The MCS lists wild-caught salmon as a 5, and rates most farmed salmon as a 3. The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists the same farmed salmon as Avoid, making it not recommended, but does specifically mention Alaskan and Coho as good options.

Name: Salmon (Coho / Silver Salmon US/Canadian Farmed)
Description: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists farmed US Coho as a Best Choice and wild Canadian Coho as a good alternative.
Explanation: The MCS lists wild-caught salmon as a 5, and rates most farmed salmon as a 3. The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists the same farmed salmon as Avoid, making it not recommended, but does specifically mention Alaskan and Coho as good options.

Name: Salmon (Alaskan)
Description: Salmon stocks in Alaska are very carefully managed and monitored, which makes this a very sustainable option.
In Season: february, march, april, may, june, july, august
Explanation: The MCS lists wild-caught salmon as a 5, and rates most farmed salmon as a 3. The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists the same farmed salmon as Avoid, making it not recommended, but does specifically mention Alaskan and Coho as good options.

Name: Salmon (Other)
Description: The environmental impact of most salmon farming and fishing is high.
Explanation: The MCS lists wild-caught salmon as a 5, and rates most farmed salmon as a 3. The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists the same farmed salmon as Avoid, making it not recommended, but does specifically mention Alaskan and Coho as good options.

Name: Sardine (Mediterranean)
Description: Small oily fish often found in tins.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates Mediterranean sardines as "Avoid" but Pacific sardines as "Best Choice". The MCS rates Atlantic sources as 2-3.

Name: Sardine (Other)
Description: Small oily fish often found in tins.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates Mediterranean sardines as "Avoid" but Pacific sardines as "Best Choice". The MCS rates Atlantic sources as 2-3.

Name: Seabass (Farmed with Recirculation System)
Description: A charismatic fish especially prized in Greece. If farmed properly, Seabass can be very sustainable.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists US black seabass caught with traps as a "Best Choice", but the MCS rates all seabass as 4-5 with the exception of seabass farmed in the UK with a recirculation system.

Name: Seabass (Other)
Description: A charismatic fish especially prized in Greece. Avoid eating seabass caught by trawling, as this is a very damaging form of fishing. Farming seabass is associated with pollution and the spread of disease to wild fish. Seabass are carnivorous fish and have to be fed on wild-caught fish that is not sourced from a sustainable supply.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists US black seabass caught with traps as a "Best Choice", but the MCS rates all seabass as 4-5 with the exception of seabass farmed in the UK with a recirculation system.

Name: Shark
Description: Predatory cartilaginous fish. They are too rare and slow-reproducing to be a sustainable food source. Many sharks are killed just for their fins, which are cut off with the shark thrown overboard to die.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates some sharks as "Good Alternative", but the MCS rates all sharks as 5, and they are are on the Greenpeace red list.

Name: Skate
Description: Cartilaginous fish with "wings" and a long, thin tail. They are severely overfished and in decline.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates MSC certified skates as a "Good Alternative" but all others "Avoid", and the MCS rate all skates as 5. Skates are on the Greenpeace red list.

Name: Snapper
Description: A number of reef-dwelling fish species, all overfished. The fishing of snappers, be they red, crimson or otherwise coloured, is also associated with a great deal of bycatch and reef destruction.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium list a large number of snapper species, some as "Avoid", others "Good Alternative". The MCS previously rated crimson snapper as 3 and red snapper as 5 and FishWatch stated that both red and vermilion snapper is overfished. Finally, red snapper is on the Greenpeace red list. In conclusion, while there are some types of snapper that may be somewhat sustainable, it is more practical to label all of them as unsustainable.

Name: Sole (MSC Certified)
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists Pacific and MSC certified sole as a "Good Alternative". The MCS lists Atlantic soles as 2-5 depending on the specific stock area and type.

Name: Sole (Pacific)
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists Pacific and MSC certified sole as a "Good Alternative". The MCS lists Atlantic soles as 2-5 depending on the specific stock area and type.

Name: Sole (Other)
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists Pacific and MSC certified sole as a "Good Alternative". The MCS lists Atlantic soles as 2-5 depending on the specific stock area and type.

Name: Spider Crab
Description: Large orange crabs. Prefer pot-caught spider crabs, as they are more sustainable.
Explanation: The MCS is currently evaluating data, but previously rated spider crabs as 2-3 depending on method of capture. The Monterey Bay Aquarium and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Spiny Lobster (Nicaragua, Honduras, Brazil)
Description: The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that spiny lobster from Mexico is sustainable, and US and Caribbean lobster is OK, while lobster from Nicaragua, Honduras and Brazil is rated as "Avoid". Lobster fisheries in Nicaragua, Honduras and Brazil are plagued with issues of overfishing, catching juveniles, and illegal fishing.

Name: Spiny Lobster (Other)
Description: The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that spiny lobster from Mexico is sustainable, and US and Caribbean lobster is OK, while lobster from Nicaragua, Honduras and Brazil is rated as "Avoid".

Name: Squid (Calamari from India, China, Thailand)
Description: Calamari from these countries should be avoided due to issues with management, bycatch, and habitat destruction.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists US Atlantic and Californian squid as a "Good Alternative", but suggests avoiding trawled calamari from India, China and Thailand. The MCS is evaluating its data but previously rated squid as 2-3.

Name: Squid (Other)
Description: All other types of squid.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists US Atlantic and Californian squid as a "Good Alternative", but suggests avoiding trawled calamari from India, China and Thailand. The MCS is evaluating its data but previously rated squid as 2-3.

Name: Stone Crab
Description: Only the claws of stone crabs are typically eaten. Claws are obtained by catching live crabs, breaking off one claw, and throwing the claw back. The crab then grows back the claw within a year.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists stone crab as a "Best Choice".

Name: Striped Bass
Description: A popular fish in the US and other countries both for sports fishing and aquaculture. Both wild-caught and farmed striped bass are sustainable: Wild stocks are at high levels, and bass are farmed in tanks, preventing environmental contamination.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium states that striped bass is not overfished and that farmed striped bass is generally raised inland avoiding ocean pollution.

Name: Sturgeon / Caviar (Farmed)
Description: Large and slow-growing, sturgeon are a very old kind of fish - so old that they do not have scales. Sturgeon can live to more than 100 years of age and only become sexually mature at 20 years or more. They are harvested for caviar.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates farmed sturgeon as a "Best Choice". The MCS rates farmed sturgeon as 2-3, but wild caught as 5.

Name: Sturgeon / Caviar (Wild Caught)
Description: Large and slow-growing, sturgeon are a very old kind of fish - so old that they do not have scales. Sturgeon can live to more than 100 years of age and only become sexually mature at 20 years or more. They are harvested for caviar.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates farmed sturgeon as a "Best Choice". The MCS rates farmed sturgeon as 2-3, but wild caught as 5.

Name: Swordfish (Harpoon Caught)
Description: Nearly all swordfish is caught by longline, which is a very disruptive method that kills sharks, turtles and sea birds. Swordfish reproduce too slowly to be a sustainable food fish. Using harpoons to catch swordfish avoids the issues of longline fishing and similar methods.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists harpooned Hawaiian and some US swordfish as "Best Choice", but other US swordfish as "Good Alternative", and other swordfish as "Avoid". The MCS lists swordfish as 2-5 depending on source. Swordfish is also on the Greenpeace red list, but they state that Hawaiian, Californian and Oregonian swordfish is well managed and a good alternative.

Name: Swordfish (Other)
Description: Nearly all swordfish is caught by longline, which is a very disruptive method that kills sharks, turtles and sea birds. Swordfish reproduce too slowly to be a sustainable food fish.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists harpooned Hawaiian and some US swordfish as "Best Choice", but other US swordfish as "Good Alternative", and other swordfish as "Avoid". The MCS lists swordfish as 2-5 depending on source. Swordfish is also on the Greenpeace red list, but they state that Hawaiian, Californian and Oregonian swordfish is well managed and a good alternative.

Name: Tiger Prawn (Organic, ASC or GlobalGAP Certified)
Description: Tiger prawns are large striped prawns. Organically certified farms vastly reduce the environmental damage that may be caused by prawn farming. Zero input farming insulates the farm from the environment, reducing environmental damage.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates imported tiger prawn as "Avoid". The MCS rates all wild fished and intensively farmed tiger prawns as 5. However, the MCS rates organic and zero input farmed tiger prawns as 1-2.

Name: Tiger Prawn (Other Farmed)
Description: Tiger prawns are large striped prawns. Prawn farming may cause: destruction of habitats through conversion into pond systems, nutrient runoff, freshwater lakes being turned into saltwater and the spread of disease to wild prawns. Prawns require a lot of fishmeal that tends to come from unclear sources.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates imported tiger prawn as "Avoid". The MCS rates all wild fished and intensively farmed tiger prawns as 5. However, the MCS rates organic and zero input farmed tiger prawns as 1-2.

Name: Tiger Prawn (Wild Caught)
Description: Tiger prawns are large striped prawns. Trawl fishing for tiger prawns produces a quarter of the world's by-catch. (Unwanted sea life that is caught and killed alongside the prawns.)
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates imported tiger prawn as "Avoid". The MCS rates all wild fished and intensively farmed tiger prawns as 5. However, the MCS rates organic and zero input farmed tiger prawns as 1-2.

Name: Tilapia
Description: A popular farmed white fish. Choose tilapia farmed in well-managed pond systems insulated from natural bodies of water is very sustainable. Look for organic Tilapia or fish produced in "closed recirculation systems".
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium lists tilapia farmed in recirculating tanks or well-managed pond systems as a Best Choice and others as a good alternative. The MCS rates tilapia as a 1-2.

Name: Trout (Rainbow Trout)
Description: A farmed freshwater fish with reddish flesh that is a popular alternative to salmon.
Explanation: Monterey Bay Aquarium states that farmed rainbow trout are a good choice. The MCS rate farmed rainbow trout as 1-3 on a scale of 5, with 1 for organic farmed trout. FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Trout (Other)
Description: Sea and lake trout are not fished sustainably.
Explanation: Monterey Bay Aquarium gives a negative picture for sea trout. MCS rate it 3. FishWatch and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Tuna (Troll/Pole-and-Line Pacific Skipjack, Yellowfin and Albacore)
Description: A family of large predatory fish with very dark meat. Look for these kinds of tuna from the Pacific caught by troll/pole-and-line fishing, which is more or less sustainable.
Explanation: Skipjack, Yellowfin and Albacore are rated by the MCS as 2-3 in certain conditions. Other species, especially Bluefin, are rated as unsustainable.

Name: Tuna (Other)
Description: A family of large predatory fish with very dark meat. Other tuna, especially bluefin, is heavily endangered and very unsustainable.
Explanation: Skipjack, Yellowfin and Albacore are rated by the MCS as 2-3 in certain conditions. Other species, especially Bluefin, are rated as unsustainable.

Name: Turbot (Farmed)
Description: A large flatfish prized for its white, subtly-flavoured flesh.
Explanation: The MCS rates all wild caught turbot as 3-5, but (onshore open circuit) farmed turbot as 2.

Name: Turbot (Wild Caught)
Description: A large flatfish prized for its white, subtly-flavoured flesh.
Explanation: The MCS rates all wild caught turbot as 3-5, but (onshore open circuit) farmed turbot as 2.

Name: Walleye (US)
Description: The walleye, not to be confused with the walleye pollock, is a fish from the US great lakes. The Environmental Defense Fund has issued a consumption advisory for walleye due to high levels of mercury and PCBs.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates walleye as a "Good Alternative". The MCS and Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Yellow Perch (US)
Description: The yellow perch is a predatory fish from the US great lakes.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium rates yellow perch as a "Best Choice"/"Good Alternative". The MCS Greenpeace have no data.

Name: Zander / Pike-Perch
Description: Sometimes called a pike-perch, the zander is a predatory fish that lives in rivers and lakes in Europe. It is a popular game and food fish. Zander not native to the UK and is considered an invasive species there.
Explanation: The Monterey Bay Aquarium, Greenpeace, the MCS, and FishWatch have no data. The IUCN rates Zander as "Least Concern".
